thread.title: The internet of things: The answer to Brexit challenges over movement of goods?

author: Angela Upex
title: The internet of things: The answer to Brexit challenges over movement of goods?
text:
Caroline Churchill, of Bond Dickinson (Image: Handout) Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
As the debates around a “hard” or “no deal” Brexit increase, businesses and particularly manufacturers, are readying themselves for a new operating environment where import tariffs could have a drastic impact on the supply chain. 
For manufacturers who rely on a timely supply of raw materials and component parts, the prospect of significant delays at ports in the UK represents a major business risk. 
Could the internet of things (IoT) play an important role in preserving frictionless borders and easing the pressures on the manufacturing sector? 
Any viable IoT solution requires a combination of technologies to succeed. Number plate recognition systems, IoT tags and GPS data could confirm container units are tracked and that they are associated with the correct unit. IoT-connected temperature gauges and CO2 detectors could provide data on the condition of perishable goods. 
Once checked by customs, real-time data transfers would allow authorised traders to speed unimpeded through a border control ‘blue lane’. 
But tapping into these technological solutions to overcome trade barriers will also result in the collection of significant volumes of commercially sensitive and personal data; therefore data law compliance will be also crucial. 
The EU’s General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) comes into operation on May 25, 2018, and post-Brexit, the UK’s Data Protection Bill will replicate its key features. 
This legislation sits uneasily with the advancements that could underpin any IoT-connected border solution if the technology which replicates data to each participating computer within the network captures personal data. 
There is a risk this may breach the GDPR unless specific legislative protection is provided. 
Manufacturers would need to consider these compliance issues when implementing these new systems. 
Manufacturers must also be confident about the security of any such system before committing commercially sensitive data. While Blockchain is touted as secure, the ‘DAO hack’ of June 2016 and subsequent breaches of Blockchain security have demonstrated that vulnerabilities exist. 
In addition, unsecured or inadequately secured IoT devices may be hijacked to launch cyber-attacks capable of bringing down major organisations. 
GDPR compliance is a significant tool to help counter this cyber threat to help make those IoT devices which handle personal data more secure. 
Time is running out, and manufacturers should consider the risks and engage in the process of designing and implementing a system capable of meeting this post-Brexit challenge. 
The IoT may just be the answer. Like us on Facebook
